transcripts.text: Do you think that you're more prepared for this pandemic because you've spent so much time with those sound-hating creatures from a quiet place?  Hey there, human.  With me, Rainn Wilson.

It's gonna be an amazing show today because of this guy, John Kwasinski, is my very special guest.  Very, very exciting.  Some other exciting news, last week I did an interview with a woman, Dr.  Lori Santos, and she is the teacher of happiness at Yale University, the most popular class in the history of Yale University.  But some of the statistics she was throwing around were really mind blowing.  It was about three blessings that if you are grateful every day and you just jot down three things that you're grateful for, that your happiness levels go up drastically.  So what Dr.  Laurie Santos was talking about was that if our happiness levels go up by 15% by simply making this list every day, simply writing down three things you're grateful for,
that
if you express that gratitude to someone on that list if you call up that person and express your gratitude to that person your happiness levels can studies have shown scientifically
stay up

It is mind-blowing how gratitude works in correlation to happiness. John Krasinski, whoever it is, if you're able to do that, your happiness levels will stay up for over a month.  It's really unbelievable.  So that's what I wanted to share with you. Dude, that's amazing.  Hey, everybody's up and have a bad day, right?

Nice.  Maybe your character on The Office had so many bad days that you burned them up.
Maybe so.  Maybe that's what it is.
You burned up all your bad days and fictitious bad days.
So how have you been doing personally?  I don't want to give your whereabouts there.
You're making it out like I'm at a CIA black site, so thank you.

Well, you know, I had someone on the show and they're like, you can't mention what city I'm in.  Yeah, because it gets tricky.  But listen, how's it been for you?  How's it been with your kids and all this and the homeschooling and all that?  How have you been surviving personally?

Well, we've been surviving.  I mean, we're very lucky and very blessed that we have each other and that, you know, everybody's happy and healthy.  And my parents and my family and Emily's parents and family, everybody's happy and healthy.  So that's the thing that matters most.  And then, no, but it's a weird thing to wrap your head around. Full stop.  And you're like, whoa, right.  Because of course, as a small person, you think this is it.  Right. I mean, hugs have become something that my girls talk about a lot.  They keep saying, I can't wait to hug my friend.  And I can't. i'm okay i'm good.  i mean i'm like you my family's all healthy and i'm lucky.  i've got a nice house and there's trees and i've got enough food.  i i've got work.  you know i i don't have to worry about being laid off or where my rent's coming from in august.  so i'm super, super grateful in these really difficult times, but yeah, doing, doing well.  And it's been, my son's a teenager.  Walter is 15 and it's been rough on him too, because all a teenager wants to do is get away from their parents and connect with their friends.  And, uh, and he's not able to, he went on a bike ride yesterday with a buddy of his just staying six feet apart, biking around the neighborhood.  So that was, that was very good for him for his mental health.

Interesting, too, because I think that part of me feels lucky sometimes to have a six year old and a three year old who, yes, feel like this is the end of their world because their world is so small and their timeline is so small.  But I really do.  It's funny.  I was just talking to my brother about this, that I really think about the kids, especially in high school, you know, Walter's age, who have lived enough life experience to know that this is very weird and, you know, that this is a new program and that we're bearing down and having to pull from somewhere deeper.  And That's a pretty massive thing.  You know, it's once in a few generations that the entire world is called upon to do something together.  So I'm thinking of him and I hope that he sees that there is something.  And I'm sure all kids in high school and college are like, whatever.  But it's like there is something that will define this generation, hopefully in a way that makes them feel like they were resilient and powerful and strong enough to get through to the next level, which is going to be great.

Listen, I said, I was talking to Steve the other day.  I said to him, if someone went into a coma like five years ago and woke up and they were asking questions about what's going on in the world and they would say, and what's the most popular television show in the world right now?  You would say The Office.  And they'd be like, what?  No, that show went off the air yesterday.  Six years?  What are you talking about?  It was popular in 2009, 10.  Isn't this crazy that we're belatedly part of this kind of international television sensation?  It's crazy.

I mean, it's astounding.  And to me, what's astounding about it is, you know, especially you and I, but anybody who is a fan of the show right from the beginning knows that we were making four episodes at a time, six episodes at a time.  We weren't even sure.  I mean, I know you remember this, but like... The folks from NBC weren't sure we were coming back ever.  I legitimately have.  I know I've told the story before, but I have a DVD that one of the guys at NBC very sweetly made me.  Jeff Engel back then was an executive who came down every Friday.  Yeah.  This show is my favorite show.  This is the last episode you're shooting.  And I was like, oh, my God.  And he and I said, could I just get the first six episodes on DVD so I can prove to my mom that I did it?  Yeah.  So I remember you and I thinking we're on the best show that nobody will ever see.  And now we're on a show that I, you know, before all this, I was at an airport and a four-year-old came up to me and was like, it's my favorite show.  And I was like, what?  What are you talking about?  So amazing that a four year old said it was their favorite show and that he watches it with his whole family.  And that again, that, that idea that everybody can watch the show.  I'm, I'm blown away.  I mean, personally, I think it's the best thing I'll ever do in my career.  I think that, you know, everybody always says, you know, you know, at the end of the day, what, you know, what if you're only known for Jim Halpert?  I was like, are you kidding me?  That would be the greatest thing ever.
And I remember that would be amazing.

I remember Steve, do you remember that?  He was like, you guys know that no matter what we go on to do, we could go to space and this will always be the thing we're known for and how lucky we are that that's the case.

Yeah.  Yeah.  He said that in the first season when we went out to lunch and, and that always stuck in my head.  I think it's stuck in all of our heads.  And the reason I'm bringing all this up is not to just throw plaudits at our old show, but also that the fact that the show is giving people so much happiness and comfort during these times, and it's a really anxious world, and the office is like this family that people are able to come back to, makes me feel really happy in my heart.  Like, oh, we had a blast.  It was a really fun run.  It was a fun run.  But most of all, the fact that It has so much heart to it that, and I remember Greg Daniels always saying like, we just want like 90% funny and like 10% heart.  But that 10% heart is I think what keeps people coming back to see the show over and over again.

I totally agree.  I also remember, I don't know if Greg told you this, but I remember Greg telling me your job on this show is not to play the lines funny.  Your job on this show is to play the lines truthfully.  And if people think that something that Jim does is funny, then that's up to them.  And if they think that there's a moment with you and Jenna, that's emotional.  That's up to them too.  We're a documentary.  So just play it for real and allow people to put their own lives on you and see what they need to see it through you.  And I remember thinking that was like, that was some like Zen Cohen kind of thing.  That was just so epic and so smart on his part.

We were so lucky to have such a great leader, but I have one last question for you before you go.  And that is, Do you think that you're more prepared for this pandemic because you've spent so much time with those sound-hating creatures from A Quiet Place?
I definitely have a more in-tune version of apocalyptic worlds ever since A Quiet Place.  Luckily, the creatures haven't shown up yet, although I am being pretty loud, so give it time.
